bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, May 18,1890

div1.p: Lazear describes his sea voyage, including the passengers, the weather, and icebergs.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, May 18,1890
div1.p:
Well, we have been
out a day now, and the weather
has been magnificent. I have
not been the least bit uncomfortable,
in fact, Norris is the only one of
our party who has been under
the weather, and as he was
sick before coming aboard,
it can hardly be called sea
sickness in his case. The only
motion the vessel has is a
very long pitch, which is
really rather pleasant. I need
not have closed the note I sent
by the pilot so soon as he did
not leave for some time after
but I did not want him to get
off without it. George Lyon said
he would send a passenger list
to you. It is very small as you
see. I am glad there are so few
as it enabled me to have my
trunk put into one of the spare state-
rooms, out of the road. I found
that my trunk was too high to go under
2
the berth, and if I had not been
able to have it in the other
state-room it would have made
it uncomfortable for me all the
way over.

I slept very well last night
and when I get used to the
difficulties of making my toilet
in such small space, with
the floor writhing under me, I shall
ask nothing more in the way
of comfort. The table is fair.
I am learning what things
to take and what to decline.
The oat-meal or “porridge” as
they call it was excellent.
I was on deck until ten last
night and I have stayed out
all day to-day except when at
meals. I am writing this in the
smoking-room which opens on
the deck.

We have had vessels of some
sort in sight all day to-day.
There was a steamer north of
us following pretty much the
same course, she has now dis-
appeared.

This afternoon the crew had “boat
drill”, getting out the life boats,
and “fire drill” which only meant
stretching out the hose and
attaching it to the pump.

Every little thing causes a sensation
on shipboard, soon after lunch
a little row boat was seen
ahead and everyone rushed ahead
forward to see what was
up. It turned out to be a boat
from a pilot-boat which we
could see at some distance
off. They came to us for some
papers; these were thrown out
to them and we passed on
leaving them astern and they
soon disappeared and the
excitement was all over
Before leaving New York I got a
copy of Marie Bashkirtseff, but
I have succeeded in reading
but a few pages. The novelty
of the sea has not worn off yet
and I enjoy simply looking about
me.

There are a number of types among
the passengers. There are several
4
English tourists, & a loud-mouthed
westerner (who is the biggest
fool on board). He attempts to
defend everything in America
that the Englishmen attack
and thus makes himself
rediculous. Then there is the
dashing girl trying to carry
on two flirtations with the
Captain and a young Scotchman.
Then there are several ladies
who are terribly sick and some
children likewise. There
is an Englishwoman, who
reminds me of the military woman
in “The Queen's Shilling,” both in
looks and actions. I thought
she would come to blows with
her husband at breakfast
this morning.

I think I prefer the inside
stateroom to the outside, it is
not so gloomy in the morning
and the air is just as good
We leave the doors into the hall
open & pull a curtain across.
Wednesday

I have let two days go by without
writing. Nothing particularly eventful
occurred until to-day and
yet the time has passed very
pleasantly. Three vessels have
passed in sight during the
three days, and one of them
came near enough to signal,
she was a Swedish brig sailing
from Hayti to Sweden.

To-day however we had a
much greater sensation in the
shape of three ice bergs. Two
of them were small and far
off and showed only as white
shining points on the horizon,
the other although quite a distance
away was of large size and
could be seen distinctly. It was
a beautiful sight, glistening
in the sun.

The weather continues beautiful
and I have had no touch of
sea-sickness. Waring succumbed
6
day before yesterday, but he is better
now, and Norris is perfectly well.
We are now abreast of the
banks of New-Foundland.

This does not mean that we
are near New-Foundland, as
the banks extend hundreds of
miles south of New Foundland.
In fact we are south of
New York our course so far having
been south by south east. We
have gone as by this route on
purpose to avoid the banks,
after we have passed them
we will change the course to
the northward. The ocean
is remarkably smooth to-day,
there is hardly a ripple on the
long ocean swells.

Some of the people on board the
boat are really very pleasant
white some are the opposite.
The loud-mouthed turns out to be a
Catholic priest and an army
chaplain in New Mexico. He has
behaved outrageously, he got beastly
7
drunk several times and went
around insulting people until
now they refuse to sell him liquor
and as he has used up what
he brought on board he is
safely disposed of. On Monday
night he tried to enter the smoking
room when he stumbled on
the sill and fell headlong
stunning himself. Two of the
stewards carried him below
and from that time they refused
to sell liquor to him.

The dashing girl I spoke about
turns out to be the wife of
one of the Dents.

There is a bride and groom on
board, who spoon continually.
Everyone is constantly catching them
at it, which is very embarrassing.
Up to Sunday night it was very
cold but since that time we have
been in the gulf-stream, and it
has been so warm that we could
sit on deck without overcoats.
It was very cold however while we
were near the ice-bergs. The temperature
of the water fell 20 degrees in an hour and a half
Friday May 23.

Our fine weather has forsaken
us for the time. All last night
and today the wind has been
very high, and we have pitched
and tossed at a great rate.
Every now and then a wave
breaks over the deck, thundering
against the cabin and soaking
any one who happens to be in its
way. Although I was out
a great deal this morning
I was fortunate in not getting
caught. One gentleman was
caught by a wave which
washed clear over the
Eua Hurricane deck. The smoke -
stack is all incrusted with
salt from the spray. This morning
before I was up four ice-bergs
were seen.

I have found it very hard to
study since I came on board.
The constant motion seems
to prevent application.

The service and table have really
been very good since the first day.

Quite a number of people succumbed
to seasickness last night and the
attendance at meals has consequently
diminished. Norris and Waring are
somewhat off to-day & Nicoll is
making a hard fight against it.
In am still feeling perfectly
comfortable, and really enjoying
the motion, I slept soundly
all last night although
the they say the rolling was
very bad.

The latest sensation aboard is
a birth which took place last
night in the steerage.

I have made friends with
the surgeon and have had
several talks with him about
Edinburgh, of which he is a
graduate.
Tues Monday.

Our gale lasted us two days but
yesterday morning we found the
sky bright and the sea smooth
and it remains so to-day.
The motion of the vessel yesterday
was so slight that it was
hardly perceptible.

It is expected that we will
see the coast of Ireland some
time tomorrow and land at
Glasgow on Wednesday afternoon
or evening.

Please tell Uncle Tom that I am
glad I took his advice and
came by the Anchor Line, the table
service and everything have been
as good as I could wish and
much better than I expected on
any steam-ship.

While the gale was on a great
many funny things occurred at
the table, the dishes slid around
in a lively way and one young lady
who is rather petite lost her
balance and slid under the
table.

I have obtained some good points
about London and Edinburgh from
Englishmen & Scotchmen on board
some ol of these men are
very pleasant indeed.

One of the amusements on board
is making a pool on the days
run. At noon the Captain
makes an observation from
which he calculates the
latitude and longitude
and from this gets the number
of miles we have travelled
in the last twenty-four hours.
Just before twelve o'clock
everyone puts a shilling in the
pool and gets a number
and when the run is announced
the one holding the correct
number gets the whole collection
I was fortunate enough to hit
the right one on Saturday.
As the winner is expected to
celebrate his victory by treating
the crowd, the actual profits
are not very large.
Wednesday May 28. 7 a.m.

We are now sailing along the coast
of Ireland, and very close in to
shore and the scenery is really
beautiful. There are little strips
of crags and little strips of beach.
Some of the hills are rocky and
some are green.

We will reach Moville at
about 8 o'clock and I will
then mail this letter and
cable if I can. We reach
Glasgow sometime this evening.
am If we arrive there early we
will go on to Edinburgh at
once, if not we will remain
over night in Glasgow.

Night before last they had a concert
on board which was hardly a
howling success, however it had
the virtue of being short.

Otherwise the life on board has
not been varied. The weather has
13
continued as fine as possible
and the days have been growing
longer and longer, until last
night it was not dusk until
after ten o'clock.

I hope to find a letter awaiting
me when I reach Edinburgh.

I intend to direct this letter
by way of Queenstown so that it
will go on one of the Wednesday
boats.

I think the trip has done me a
great deal of good, I have not had
a moments sickness, nor have I lost
any sleep.

I hope you have been perfectly well
while I have been making this
long journey over the ocean blue.

A peculiar thing about an ocean
trip is that you do not feel
longing for a newspaper at breakfast.
I really lost all curiosity as to
the news of the day. I suppose I
shall learn today what has
happened during the last eleven
days. Yo

I will write again when I get
to Edinburgh

Give my love all at Uncle Tom's
and at the Miller's.
div1.closer:
Your affectionate Son J.W.L. Please don't hand any of my
letters around to be read.
